metadata.case_name: Milan Banik v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: District Magistrate Burdwan ordered detention of petitioner under section 3 of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 (Act 26 of 1971) on June 1, 1973 to prevent him from acting prejudicial to maintenance of public order.
DM sent report to State Government with grounds of detention and particulars; approved on June 12, 1973.
Petitioner arrested on July 23, 1973 and served with detention order, grounds, and vernacular translation.
Case placed before Advisory Board on August 7, 1973.
State Government received petitioner's representation on August 7, 1973; rejected it on August 8, 1973 and forwarded to Advisory Board.
Advisory Board opined on September 25, 1973 that there was sufficient cause for detention.
State Government confirmed detention order on October 1, 1973.

On 8-5-73 at about 04.00 hrs. petitioner along with associates stopped rickshaw of Sri Gopal Sharma on point of dagger, snatched Rs. 20/- and valuables, creating panic and disturbing normal avocations.

On 15-5-73 at about 04.30 hours petitioner along with associates Swapan Singh and others attacked Shri Aditya Mondal, bus conductor, on point of Bhojali, robbed Rs. 30/-, wrist watch, valuables; terrorised people, disturbed flow of life.
Two cases registered against petitioner for above activities; final reports submitted, petitioner discharged as witnesses unwilling due to fear.

legal_issues.text: Whether alleged activities were germane to public order or merely law and order.
Whether grounds of detention were vague for not mentioning names of all associates.
Whether detention valid despite registration of criminal cases and discharge for same activities.
Whether confirmation of detention order infirm for not specifying period of detention.

petitioner_arguments.text: Alleged activities not germane to public order.
Grounds of detention vague as names of all associates not mentioned.
Cannot detain under MISA for activities where criminal cases registered and petitioner discharged.
State Government did not specify period of detention while confirming order.

respondent_arguments.text: Activities created panic, disturbed normal life, nexus to public order.
Grounds specified date, time, place, nature; not vague.
No legal bar to detention despite criminal cases/discharge due to witness fear.

court_reasoning.text: Activities have direct nexus with public order as they disturbed even tempo of life; test: interferes with current of community life (Kanu Biswas v. State of West Bengal).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Robberies terrorised locals, created panic, people afraid to go out.

court_reasoning.text: Sushanta Goswami distinguished as no panic/disturbance shown there.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner cannot derive help from that case.

court_reasoning.text: Grounds not vague: date, time, place, nature specified; sufficient for effective representation (Sk. Hasan Ali v. State of West Bengal).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Non-mention of all associates' names does not vitiate.

court_reasoning.text: No bar to detention despite criminal cases/discharge; detaining authority can act if activities justify (Sasti Satish Chowdhary; Mohd. Salini Khan; Sahib Singh Duggal).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Witness fear explains discharge; incidents germane.

court_reasoning.text: No infirmity in not specifying period on confirmation; section does not require it, max 2 years (Suna Ulla v. State of J&K).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Confirmation allows continuation for period Government thinks fit.

holdings.text: Activities affect public order, not merely law and order.
Detention valid despite prior criminal proceedings and discharge.
No need to specify detention period in confirmation order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kanu Biswas v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Test for public order vs law and order.
Detenu released despite dagger snatch; no panic shown.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sk. Hasan Ali v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Grounds not vague despite unnamed associates.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sasti Satish Chowdhary v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: No bar to detention despite IPC offence/criminal proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohd. Salini Khan v. Shri C. C. Bose Anr.
precedents_cited.citation: Writ Petition No. 435 of 1971 decided on April 25, 1972
precedents_cited.relevance: Discharge in criminal case does not invalidate detention.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sahib Singh Duggal v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports no inference of mala fides from discharge.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suna Ulla v. State of J. K.
precedents_cited.relevance: No need to specify period in confirmation under analogous Act.

statutes_cited.name: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for detention order to prevent prejudicial acts.

statutes_cited.name: Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogous provision; no requirement to specify period on confirmation.

outcome.summary: All contentions of petitioner rejected; detention order upheld as valid under MISA.

key_quotes.text: The test for determining whether a particular activity affects law and order or whether it impinges upon public order is Does it interfere with the current of life of the community so as to amount to disturbance of public order...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines distinction between law/order and public order.

key_quotes.text: The fact that the particular act of the detenu which provides the reason for the making of the detention order constitutes an offence under the Indian Penal Code would not prevent the detaining authority from passing the order for detention...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies no bar to preventive detention despite criminal liability.
